title: TTF: Exchange Rate Remains Top Concern For Tourism Operators - SurveyTravelandtourworld.com
text:
TTF: Exchange Rate Remains Top Concern For Tourism Operators – Survey Published on : Thursday, July 2, 2015
The level of the exchange rate remains the chief concern among local tourism businesses despite further depreciation of the Australian dollar, according to a survey released today by national peak body Tourism & Transport Forum Australia (TTF) and MasterCard.
“While a cheaper Aussie Dollar is generally good news for Australia’s tourism, the industry remains concerned about the negative impact of the currency exchange rates on their business,” TTF CEO Margy Osmond said today.
“This is most likely the result of the currency not depreciating by as much against the currencies of key tourism source markets such as New Zealand, the UK and Europe.”
The TTF-MasterCard Tourism Survey Industry Sentiment Survey (March) also found:
· Access to labour is a major issue for many tourism businesses, with over 1 in 5 respondents nominating skilled (26%) and unskilled labour (21%) as one of their top three impediments. · Softer domestic outcomes are being offset by strong international results. · Australia’s reputation as a desirable destination is under pressure.
“With intense competition for international visitors, we need to work hard to cement Australia’s status as a great destination through consistent and well-funded marketing campaigns,” Ms Osmond said.
“We also need to address the taxes and charges on tourists which harm Australia’s appeal with international visitors and act as a handbrake on an industry with huge job-creating potential.
“Tourism has been identified as an industry with the potential to boost our national economy, create jobs and grow prosperity, so it’s important these issues are addressed.”
The TTF-MasterCard Tourism Survey Industry Sentiment Survey is the leading independent measure of key industry themes and trends. The survey is distributed to senior staff within TTF’s membership organisations and other leading tourism businesses around Australia.
